reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s reliance on the “approximately linear-in-resources, non-discounting” preference class, which the essay uses as a key pivot for (i) whether abundance yields altruistic allocation and (ii) whether moral trade/compromise is likely to produce mostly-great futures. Undermining that pivot would weaken an important branch of the essay’s argument about trade pessimism (especially §3.2/§3.4), but would not collapse the broader thesis (which also leans heavily on anti-/realism, motivation, threats, power concentration, and institutional blockers). The objection has moderate strength: it plausibly shows under-justification and a potential knife-edge in how conclusions shift across preference-curvature regimes, but it doesn’t provide a positive case that linearity is unlikely, nor does it fully engage with the essay’s own acknowledgements of uncertainty and partial robustness claims. The critique is mostly correct, clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Unjustified linear-utility assumptions drive the paper’s pessimism about trade and compromise
